channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Former Trump aide John Bolton to make first court appearance in classified documents case
item.description: The former national security adviser surrendered to federal officials in Maryland on Friday, a day after his indictment on charges that he mishandled classified materials.

item.title: John Bolton. Trump-Zelensky meeting. ICE surveillance. Shutdown deadlock. Venezuela. Fertility drugs. Roman mystery. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: These two quick tests can tell you if you’re as fit as an 80-year-old elite athlete
item.description: The tests require only a chair, a willing helper, a stopwatch and few spare minutes.

item.title: Susan Stamberg dies at 87. A ‘founding mother’ of NPR, she helped blaze a trail for women in broadcasting.
item.description: As a host of “All Things Considered,” she was the first woman to anchor a national nightly news program in the United States.

item.title: Ace Frehley, the galvanizing guitarist who helped make Kiss one of the biggest rock groups of the 1970s and ’80s, dies at 74
item.description: Taking the blues rock of his favorite bands, Frehley imbued the group with energy and leaned into the theatrics as a performer.

item.title: Top military officer central to Trump’s drug war to step down early
item.description: Adm. Alvin Holsey has served as the head of U.S. Southern Command for less than a year. The position typically rotates every three years.

item.title: Former national security adviser John Bolton indicted for allegedly mishandling sensitive documents
item.description: Bolton is the third long-time target of President Donald Trump to be charged in a month.

item.title: Chamber of Commerce sues Trump to block $100,000 fee for H-1B visas — its first legal action against the administration this term
item.description: The powerful business group is alleging that President Donald Trump’s changes to the immigration pathway widely used by Silicon Valley are illegal.

item.title: Trump unveils plan to make IVF and fertility drugs more accessible and affordable, a key campaign pledge
item.description: President Donald Trump made broadening access to in vitro fertilization a 2024 campaign pillar as he looked to make up for losses among female voters in the aftermath of Roe v. Wade’s fall.

item.title: Happening now: How big will the ‘No Kings’ protests be this weekend? Our chief political correspondent takes your questions.
item.description: Happening now: How big will the ‘No Kings’ protests be this weekend? Our chief political correspondent takes your questions.

item.title: I resigned from the military because of Trump
item.description: I could not swear to follow a commander in chief who seems so willing to disregard the Constitution.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Soon-to-be dad goes bungee jumping, comes home to furious wife
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Soon-to-be dad goes bungee jumping, comes home to furious wife

item.title: U.S. Special Operations copters fly less than 90 miles from Venezuela, suggesting possible preparation for missions inside country
item.description: The U.S. military’s elite Special Operations aviation unit appears to have flown in Caribbean waters near the coast of Venezuela in recent days, according to a visual analysis by The Washington Post.

item.title: Don’t be ‘weak’ in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: ‘It broke me’: Inside the FBI hunt for the online predators who persuaded a 13-year-old to kill himself
item.description: How the suicide of a child from Washington state launched a years-long global investigation to find an elusive online user called “White Tiger,” with one FBI agent saying he encountered brutality and bureaucratic hurdles in the case that challenged him in ways he’d never faced.

item.title: Shutdown layoffs. Voting maps. Pentagon. Venezuela pressure. Medicare portal glitches. ‘Quality’ jobs. Fitness test. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump’s team made a Medicare doctor directory a priority. It launched with errors, The Post found, setting off a scramble.
item.description: The directory, intended to help older Americans navigate Medicare Advantage open enrollment, produces conflicting responses about which providers are covered by health plans.

item.title: Public executions. Hunting rival gangs. Hamas launches a new, violent campaign to reassert control over Gaza.
item.description: Amid the ceasefire with Israel, Hamas is sending a message that it remains the only visible authority in Gaza, with huge implications for President Donald Trump’s peace plan.

item.title: Trump says he has authorized covert CIA action in Venezuela
item.description: President Donald Trump said Wednesday that he had authorized the Central Intelligence Agency to conduct operations in Venezuela, markedly escalating U.S. pressure on President Nicolás Maduro amid a string of lethal strikes against alleged drug trafficking boats in Caribbean waters off that country’s coast.

item.title: No amount of alcohol is safe if you aim to avoid dementia, a new study suggests
item.description: The finding comes from the data of more than 550,000 adults and genetics information from 2.4 million study participants. It adds to emerging evidence that a drink or two a day isn’t risk-free.

item.title: Teens avoided incarceration for attacking a former DOGE staffer. Trump officials quickly asserted the penalty was too lenient.
item.description: Two teens arrested in connection with the attempted carjacking of a former U.S. DOGE Service staffer in August were sentenced to probation. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt and U.S. Attorney for D.C. Jeanine Pirro swiftly revived the Trump administration’s criticism that young people who commit crimes in D.C. do not receive harsh enough punishments.

item.title: Judge orders Trump administration to pause layoffs during government shutdown
item.description: Senior U.S. District Judge Susan Illston temporarily blocked the Trump administration’s plans to lay off thousands of federal workers during the shutdown, siding with unions that have argued the dismissals were illegal.

item.title: Supreme Court seems open to limiting a key section of the Voting Rights Act that allows the use of race to draw legislative maps
item.description: A ruling that eliminates or severely cuts back Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act would most likely lead to a decline in the number of minorities holding public office. It would also touch off a scramble to redraw electoral maps across the country.

item.title: Georgetown University names Eduardo M. Peñalver as its next president. Here are 4 things to know about him.
item.description: Peñalver, 52, is the president of Seattle University, also a Jesuit institution. Georgetown’s board of directors chose him after a search to replace longtime president John J. DeGioia, who stepped down last November to recover from a stroke.

item.title: Will my husband’s long-distance job ruin our marriage? Carolyn Hax’s readers give advice.
item.description: Will my husband’s long-distance job ruin our marriage? Carolyn Hax’s readers give advice.

item.title: Is it America’s fate to decline and fall? History offers signs — and solutions.
item.description: Is it America’s fate to decline and fall? Here’s what history says.

item.title: Say goodbye to Post food critic Tom Sietsema in his final dining chat
item.description: After 25 years, The Washington Post’s food critic is stepping down, so get in your last questions and comments now.

item.title: A turtleneck kind of gal in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Gaza’s future. Venezuela strike. Charlie Kirk. Utility bills. Alcohol and dementia. D’Angelo. Uncrustables dupe. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Six recession warning signs to watch: Thrifting is up, but cardboard boxes are down
item.description: The United States is not in — or even near — a recession, despite so many “indicators” online. But the economy is in an uncertain place. Here’s what you really need to pay attention to.

item.title: U.S. kills six alleged drug smugglers in new strike off Venezuela, Trump says
item.description: The operation follows Senate Republicans’ narrow defeat of a measure that aimed to prevent the administration’s actions on legal grounds.

item.title: D’Angelo dies at 51. The visionary musician helped pioneer the neo-soul movement, releasing acclaimed albums such as ‘Voodoo.’
item.description: The cause of death was cancer, according to a statement from his family. Born Michael Archer, D’Angelo helped launch a new era for R&B, nodding to an old-school soul sound while incorporating notes of funk, hip-hop and jazz. Dubbed “neo-soul” by his music manager, the subgenre became a mainstay of 1990s pop.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Is it rude when one partner walks too fast for the other?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Is it rude when one partner walks too fast for the other?

item.title: Gen Z slang is everywhere. Test your knowledge of teen talk with this quiz.
item.description: Today’s teen slang is more absurd, global-reaching and irony-laden, thanks to TikTok.

item.title: Supreme Court rejects Alex Jones’s bid to set aside $1.4 billion verdict for defaming Sandy Hook families
item.description: Jones, a conspiracy theorist and founder of InfoWars, had asked the justices to pause the award and take up an appeal of the civil case against him. He was found liable in 2022 of falsely claiming that the 2012 mass killing at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut was a hoax.

item.title: Butterfly in the sky in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: The U.S. saved him from the Taliban. Trump wants to send him back.
item.description: He supported the American war, escaped Afghanistan and started a family in the United States. Then Immigration and Customs Enforcement arrested him, and if he is deported, he expects the Taliban to kill him.

item.title: Trump’s victory lap. Shutdown impact. Pentagon press. Heath insurance. Coastal storm. Pot science. Shoulder stretch. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Despite reversal of hundreds of CDC layoffs, federal biodefense workers are among health staff who still lost jobs, officials say
item.description: Officials have reversed more than half of the about 1,300 layoff notices sent to staff at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, sparing personnel who were leading the response to measles outbreaks in the United States and an Ebola outbreak abroad. But details emerged about the other health workers who lost their jobs.

item.title: Microplastics are everywhere. You can do one simple thing to avoid them.
item.description: The biggest sources of microplastics have one thing in common, scientists say.

item.title: Prominent news outlets reject Pentagon’s press policy before signing deadline
item.description: The Washington Post joined the New York Times, CNN and the Atlantic in refusing to sign the policy, which says that reporters cannot obtain or solicit any information that the Defense Department does not explicitly authorize.

item.title: A surge in retirements is putting huge strains on the government as it deals with a shutdown and layoffs
item.description: The mass exodus — unprecedented in its scale — includes 154,000 federal employees who accepted buyout offers and were largely removed from the payroll as of the end of last month. Some of those are among nearly 105,000 employees who took regular retirement during the fiscal year that ended in September, an 18 percent surge from the previous year.

item.title: Remembering Sister Jean in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Trump declares 'dawn of a new Middle East,' celebrating return of all living hostages to Israel
item.description: President Donald Trump is addressing the Israeli parliament after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called him “the greatest friend that the state of Israel has ever had in the White House.” All 20 living hostages have been returned to Israel from Gaza, and Israel has begun releasing Palestinian prisoners and detainees. Follow our live coverage.

item.title: Hostage release. Shutdown impacts. Blue states. Deadly explosion. Gender pay gap. AI videos. Longevity tips. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Nobel prize in economics awarded to trio for their work explaining creative destruction in innovation, growth
item.description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded to Joel Mokyr of Northwestern University, Philippe Aghion of College de France, INSEAD and the London School of Economics, and Peter Howitt of Brown University.

item.title: Hamas releases first seven Israeli hostages as swap brokered under ceasefire deal gets underway
item.description: The group, who were handed over to the International Committee of the Red Cross, are among the last living captives in Gaza about two years after Hamas-led militants attacked Israel, unleashing Israel’s destructive war in the Gaza Strip

item.title: A conservative influencer was arrested in Portland. The president was watching.
item.description: After Nick Sortor was arrested earlier this month outside an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Portland, Oregon, President Donald Trump latched on to justify a federal crackdown.

item.title: The pain from the government shutdown is about to hit the public
item.description: Americans are bracing for the worst effects of the ongoing shutdown to collide with the U.S. economy this week as missed paychecks and the absence of billions of dollars of government services sink in.
